question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: It was a flipped classroom environment, which I think could work well for a Chinese class with a textbook like this. I liked the idea of the flipped classroom, but it ended up being quite stressful when the preview assignments were graded for accuracy and not completion - it felt like we had to completely understand the material before coming to class, instead of simply being exposed to it, which was stressful and not helpful I think, leading some to sue AI/translation just to get the assignments done rather than actually trying their best.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the collaborative nature of the class, especially because we only had like nine people in our class. 周老师 makes sure everyone participates so you will definitely get a chance to hear everyone's voice and get comfortable with your peers. Though they took some time, the preview homework assignments due before the start of each lecture allowed us to learn the content before class and practice it effectively during class. I also really appreciated the weekly one-on-one (一对一) conversations we had outside of class. For about twenty minutes each week, we would meet with a TA and read through passages, have conversations about the current lesson topic, and examine other supplementary material all in Chinese. I think this probably helped me improve my speaking the most!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: CHN 203 is definitely a real course (all assessments are typed, though! no handwriting except for like a third of the workbook assignments, but they're for homework so you don't have to memorize how to write the characters). To be honest, you could probably do decent in the course without putting in a ton of work if you have more time-intensive courses as long as you read the textbook and pay attention in class. For me, I put in a lot of work studying and I found it to be rewarding both in class lectures, the 一对一 conversations, and on the tests. I think the course definitely gets harder as the semester progresses, but you will also get more comfortable with the format of the class. The quizzes are genuinely not that bad (part 1: they will read three sentences and you type them up, part 2: they will read two questions and you type up your answers, part 3: unscramble two sentences that are shown on the board), but you should definitely make sure you know the grammar very well before the tests (a lot of us end up using the full class period). You also need to talk enough in class to get full participation points, but I was on the quieter side and still ended up getting 9.5/10 for the participation + attendance, so take that as you will. Oh, also the 一对一's are really not as bad as they sound, most of the time is spent reviewing the content in class so as long as you studied the lesson you'll be fine. I was really nervous for my first 一对一 but I ended up enjoying the experience a lot!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: CHN 203 is definitely a real course (all assessments are typed, though! no handwriting except for like a third of the workbook assignments, but they're for homework so you don't have to memorize how to write the characters). To be honest, you could probably do decent in the course without putting in a ton of work if you have more time-intensive courses as long as you read the textbook and pay attention in class. For me, I put in a lot of work studying and I found it to be rewarding both in class lectures, the 一对一 conversations, and on the tests. I think the course definitely gets harder as the semester progresses, but you will also get more comfortable with the format of the class. The quizzes are genuinely not that bad (part 1: they will read three sentences and you type them up, part 2: they will read two questions and you type up your answers, part 3: unscramble two sentences that are shown on the board), but you should definitely make sure you know the grammar very well before the tests (a lot of us end up using the full class period). You also need to talk enough in class to get full participation points, but I was on the quieter side and still ended up getting 9.5/10 for the participation + attendance, so take that as you will. Oh, also the 一对一's are really not as bad as they sound, most of the time is spent reviewing the content in class so as long as you studied the lesson you'll be fine. I was really nervous for my first 一对一 but I ended up enjoying the experience a lot!

My Chinese has definitely improved a lot throughout this course, especially my understanding of Chinese culture and my ability to talk/read/write/listen on more complex high level topics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it. Shu Zhang is a wonderful professor and she has been one of the best chinese professors I have had at Duke. She makes it easy to follow along and she is very good at explaining certain structures that didn’t make any sense.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to spend a lot of effort on this class and make sure your other classes are not too heavy on workload. Make sure you are at a good level of Chinese and it will be rewarding if you stay on top of your work and gain speaking practice.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would absolutely consider taking this class, as it is a perfect capstone to the language requirement and prepares students well for interactions in Chinese.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
If you're coming into this course from 204, anticipate that the pace will be somewhat faster, and you will need to study significantly more vocabulary per lesson. Keep on top of your quizzes and preview assignments, and you should be well prepared for everything else. Study your vocab incrementally and don't wait to cram right before the exam, which might let you scrape by, but will not help you actually retain the vocabulary or grammar.
Zhang Laoshi is an excellent instructor. She's very personable and engaging, and she's also very understanding. If you're having difficulties, please reach out to her, as she wants her students to succeed, and will do her best to assist you. The Chinese department in general is wonderful. I have nothing but positive things to say about the program and faculty!
(I mentioned above that my engagement with the course was moderate. This isn't by any fault of the course or instructor. This semester has just been a bit tough for me for unrelated reasons.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned chinese! I also learned a lot about Chinese culture, Singapore's culture, and the differences between the East and the West.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about a lot of cultural topics in China. This included values of face/image, courtesy/respect, and mediation/the golden mean. We also learned over 50 new words in Chinese each week, in addition to ~5 new grammatical concepts each week. There were many relevant communication examples to help us understand these concepts which were sometimes complicated.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learnt about the behavioral expectations of Chinese culture. We learnt that Chinese culture tends to prioritize unity and advocate forbearance to achieve it. When criticizing others, it is important to find a middle man and to not do so in front of everyone. Additionally, fame is often seen as dangerous as it invites criticism and trouble.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how Chinese values can permeate the political and social in implicit ways, shaping Chinese society. This course taught me how to more critically view modern day events from this lens.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor made sure to call on different students and give everyone a chance to practice their Chinese in class as well as share their ideas. This made class discussion and lot more fun/interesting, and gave students (who take a longer time to think of what they want to say) time to process questions then answer thoughtfully. I also like the class structure in general of spending a whole week to review one lesson from the textbook. I think the communication scenarios and miscommunication analyses really deepened my understanding of each lesson and taught me a lot of new vocabulary/idioms. I also really liked that we got the chance to interview a Chinese friend about each lesson and were encouraged to practice Chinese outside of class. Additionally, the videos reviewing 近义词 were very helpful, because in past Chinese classes, I would take notes and Google information about 近义词 I noticed by myself, so it was nice to have a specific resource explaining the differences for me.

I enjoy the lecture and discussion based format for this class and both of these components have given me the opportunity to not only have an academic understanding of Chinese grammar and syntax, but also be able to practice in a supportive and collaborative environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a Chinese American, there are many similarities on how we think and how traditional Chinese’s think, but I’ve learned there are still quite a difference from these two groups. I learned that Traditional Chinese people are hidden with people that they don’t know, so they keep many personal things away while still trying to be polite. They also have their own kind of “politeness” which causes them to act or think in a different way that is normally thought. Finally, they like to exaggerate how they are lower/less accomplished while enhancing other’s achievements.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The workload can be daunting at first, but as long as you preview the content and study the vocabulary early (maybe starting on Saturday/Sunday at the latest), the quizzes will be manageable. Do not try to study the vocabulary/reading the day of, because you won't absorb anything, and a lot of the quizzes focus on recognizing pretty complex characters and certain ideas mentioned in the text. Start on the essays early; the worksheets are more manageable, but the essays are graded more strictly and take a lot of time to outline, compose, and edit. Exams are decently fair, and as long as you study the vocabulary and review the class slides, you'll be fine.

course: CHINESE-407S-01 : ISSUES IN CHINESE LANG/SOC I.CHINESE-407S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

course: CHINESE-407S-01 : ISSUES IN CHINESE LANG/SOC I.CHINESE-407S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The weekly essays were busy work. Also, I was never told when we had an essay or when an essay was due, so it was hard to know when an essay was due. Essaying grading is also weird. Essay grading isn't based on whether a sentence is grammatically correct, but whether the course TA believes the word is the most formal. The problem with this is that what the TA thinks is formal is not the same as what students think is formal because everyone's approach to writing Chinese depends on regions of China they grow up in. In many ways, this grading system is discriminatory against non-heritage speakers, along with heritage speakers who grow up in other areas of China.

course: CHINESE-407S-01 : ISSUES IN CHINESE LANG/SOC I.CHINESE-407S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is very intellectually stimulating, but I would only recommend taking it if your Chinese proficiency is good enough. Most native speakers who test into this class are qualified to get an A- or A, but this course is significantly harder for non-native speakers just due to the amount of vocabulary and writing they are expected to complete each class. I felt that the workload is generally ok, but I spent significantly more time when essays or review tests were coming up. I would also say that you are expected to participate a decent amount each class given the small class size - if you are not willing to voice your opinion or have a discussion on societal issues, I would reconsider.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Honestly, it was a good class but I don't think I would take it knowing how much work it consisted of. There are 2-3 quizzes for every movie (i think we watched 8) meaning we had quizzes pretty much every week. There are 3 midterms. You have to watch the movies outside of class yourself and do lots of homework questions for every class (on top of studying new words). You have to do a presentation on a movie, there were around 2 essays throughout the semester, and at the end you have to write a 2000-3000 word paper and do a presentation on it. It was an interesting class, but it just took up a lot of time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I highly appreciated the out of class discussion sections, and the invited lectures. I also really enjoyed the news-sharing and philosophy-comparison projects, which enabled us to dig deeper. Overall I enjoyed how the class facilitated discussion between peers, which allowed us to get to know each other better and create a great environment for learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the integration of physical exercises into our learning about Chinese philosophy. The pre-tests helped to focus my understanding of the implications of the readings. However, I was surprised by the degree that the pre-tests and some of the classroom instruction assumed that there is only one possible interpretation of the text and that that interpretation must be credulous and laudatory. However, I do understand the impulse to defend subaltern and non-Western traditions from Western chauvinism. On the other hand, China has become a super-power, so both Chinese and non-Chinese people need to be allowed space to take a critical perspective on the philosophical foundations of Chinese politics and foreign policy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Research Skills:One key takeaway from this course was the development of robust research skills. Through various assignments and projects, I learned how to conduct comprehensive literature reviews, critically analyze research articles, and apply research methodologies to answer specific questions. This skill set has not only enhanced my academic capabilities but also prepared me for future endeavors that involve evidence-based decision-making.
Interdisciplinary Thinking:The course encouraged an interdisciplinary approach to problem-solving. I gained insights into how diverse fields contribute to a holistic understanding of complex issues. By engaging with content from various perspectives—such as psychology, sociology, and economics—I learned to appreciate the interconnectedness of knowledge domains. This has broadened my thinking and allowed me to approach challenges with a more comprehensive and nuanced mindset.
Effective Communication:Another valuable skill I developed was effective communication. The course emphasized the importance of conveying complex ideas clearly and persuasively. Through presentations, discussions, and written assignments, I honed my ability to articulate thoughts, support arguments with evidence, and engage with diverse audiences. This skill is not only vital for academic success but is also applicable in professional settings where clear communication is essential.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This Chinese class has been an exceptional learning experience, significantly enriching my understanding and appreciation of Chinese language and culture. Firstly, I've noticed a substantial improvement in my Chinese writing skills. The course's focus on integrating learning about Chinese mythologies and traditional stories into our writing exercises not only enhanced my language proficiency but also deepened my engagement with the material.Secondly, the class illuminated aspects of Chinese culture and history that were entirely new to me. Although I consider myself to be fairly knowledgable about Chinese culture, the class nevertheless significantly broadened my horizon of cultural perception and introduced complex ideas and historical contexts that I had not encountered before, fostering a greater appreciation for the nuances of Chinese cultural heritage. Alongside this, the development of my critical thinking skills was particularly emphasized, teaching me to analyze and interpret historical and cultural information critically and thoughtfully.Lastly, the course challenged me to view Chinese history and culture through a new lens. This approach was incredibly enriching and eye-opening, as it allowed me to see the diversity and depth of Chinese mythologies and history in ways I had not previously considered. Using both an academic lens and a colloquial lens consisting of films, multimedia, and stories, Professor Jiang offered an incredibly engaging, thought provoking class and  facilitated incredibly rigorous in-class discussions and debates of the influences shaping modern China and mythologies. Overall, this course has not only bolstered my language skills but also profoundly expanded my cultural knowledge and analytical abilities, making it a truly invaluable educational journey.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, the exceptional instructional methods employed by Dr. Jiang played a pivotal role in facilitating an engaging and effective learning experience. Her deep knowledge, patience, and caring nature created a supportive and encouraging classroom atmosphere. Dr. Jiang's personalized approach to giving feedback on our individual assignments and presentation styles was particularly invaluable. This not only helped improve my language skills but also boosted my confidence in public speaking and academic writing in Chinese.Furthermore, Dr. Jiang's innovative use of creative writing assignments and in-class debates greatly enhanced my engagement with the course material. These methods allowed us to explore Chinese mythologies in depth and from multiple perspectives, enriching our understanding and appreciation of the stories. Her ability to facilitate discussions effectively ensured that every voice was heard, fostering a dynamic and interactive learning environment. The debates and discussions prompted critical thinking and allowed us to delve deeper into complex cultural concepts, making each class session both challenging and rewarding.I would strongly advocate for the continuation of these interactive components in future courses. The creative writing assignments encourage creative expression and deeper cultural immersion, while the in-class debates enhance critical thinking and engagement. Dr. Jiang’s discussion facilitation style not only makes the material more accessible but also more compelling, significantly contributing to a lively and inclusive classroom atmosphere.Overall, Dr. Jiang’s teaching methods are a testament to her dedication and skill as an educator, and they have profoundly impacted my studies in Chinese language and culture. Her approach should certainly be a model for future courses, ensuring that students not only learn effectively but are also deeply engaged with the material.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class is intellectually stimulating for two reasons.First, the class's use of in-class debates and interactive discussions make the course material extremely easy to engage. From "The Tale of White Snake" （白蛇传） to the founding world myths of China （创世神话）, I found Dr. Jiang puts a lot of attention into all components of the course to make the course engaging for students from all ranges of academic backgrounds and class years with different levels of Chinese skills. Her careful attention ensures that the course is accessible and engaging for students from diverse academic backgrounds and varying levels of Chinese proficiency. This method not only makes the material more relatable but also fosters a dynamic learning environment where students feel encouraged to participate and express their ideas.Second, the class is also stimulating for the critical thinking skills that it practices. In class, we engage a lot in exploring different sides of the course material to build our critical thinking and evaluation skills. This practice not only deepens our understanding of Chinese culture and mythologies but also enhances our overall analytical abilities. Dr. Jiang's emphasis on critical thinking prepares students to handle nuanced discussions and to approach problems with a sophisticated analytical lens.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You definitely don't need any prior Chinese knowledge to learn in this class, but I would have a plan in how you're going to take away the lessons in the class. It's not structured for people who haven't had the experience of learning a language before. For instance, if the important thing for you is learning as much vocabulary in the class, I would prioritize pronunciation and retention of vocabulary. If it's learning how to string words together, then I would focus on the grammar structure more. If you just want to get used to listening in Chinese, I would pay attention in how Professor Liu speaks to the class, etc.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend this course if you have any interest in learning Chinese but do not want to commit to the full 101 course. This provides a low stress and fun entry way into learning that I really liked. Learning tones was a little challenging, but if you stick with it they aren't too bad to pick up. That said, you will get out what you put in. It is a half credit course, so it is pretty easy to get the S while staying unengaged, but if you actually engage with the content and try it was really enjoyable and you can build a solid foundation.
